title: Garland Green
text:
Garland Green (born Garfield Green Jr., June 14, 1942) is an American <a href="soul%20music">soul</a> <a href="singing">singer</a> and <a href="pianist">pianist</a>.
Biography.
Born in <a href="Dunleith%2C%20Mississippi">Dunleith</a>, <a href="Mississippi">Mississippi</a>, United States, Green was the tenth child of eleven in his family. He lived in Mississippi until 1958 when he moved to <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>. While working and attending Englewood High, he sang on weekends, and one day while singing in a pool room, he was overheard by Argia B. Collins, a local owner of a barbeque chain. Collins agreed to bankroll Green's attendance at the <a href="Chicago%20Conservatory%20of%20Music">Chicago Conservatory of Music</a>, where Green studied <a href="human%20voice">voice</a> and <a href="piano">piano</a>, and played in local bars and clubs.
In 1967, Green won a local talent show at a club called the Trocadero. His prize was a <a href="concert">concert</a> opening for <a href="Lou%20Rawls">Lou Rawls</a> and <a href="Earl%20Hines">Earl Hines</a> at the Sutherland Lounge. In the audience was Mel Collins, and his wife <a href="Joshie%20Jo%20Armstead">Joshie Jo Armstead</a>, who was a <a href="songwriter">songwriter</a> who had written tunes with <a href="Nick%20Ashford">Nick Ashford</a> and <a href="Valerie%20Simpson">Valerie Simpson</a> prior to the couple joining <a href="Motown%20Records">Motown</a>. The couple arranged for Green to do a <a href="sound%20recording%20and%20reproduction">recording</a> session in <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a> and released the result as a <a href="single%20%28music%29">single</a> on their <a href="record%20label">label</a>, <a href="Gamma%20Records">Gamma Records</a>, a song called "Girl I Love You", written by <a href="Shelley%20Fisher">Shelley Fisher</a>. It sold well locally and was picked up by <a href="MCA%20Records">MCA</a> subsidiary, <a href="Revue%20Records">Revue Records</a> for national distribution. Revue released three further singles from Green who then moved to MCA's main label, <a href="Uni%20Records">Uni Records</a>.
In 1969, "Jealous Kind of Fella" became a major national success, reaching No. 5 in the "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" <a href="Hot%20R%26amp%3BB/Hip-Hop%20Songs">R&B</a> <a href="record%20chart">chart</a> and No. 2 in the <a href="Cash%20Box">Cashbox</a> <a href="soul%20music">soul</a> chart.
Written by Green, R. Browner, M. Dollinson and Jo Armstead, the <a href="gramophone%20record">record</a> was released in the <a href="United%20States">U.S.</a> in August 1969. It sold a million copies by March 1971. Uni released an <a href="album">album</a> from Green, but the follow-up single did not sell well and Green eventually left MCA, also parting company with Armstead. He then signed with <a href="Atlantic%20Records">Atlantic Records</a> subsidiary, <a href="Cotillion%20Records">Cotillion Records</a>, which released five singles from Garland, but only one proved a real success, "Plain and Simple Girl". <a href="Record%20producer">Produced</a> and <a href="arrangement">arranged</a> by <a href="Donny%20Hathaway">Donny Hathaway</a>, this reached the R&B Top 20.
Moving on to <a href="Spring%20Records">Spring Records</a> in 1973, Green recorded five more singles, some of which charted modestly, notably "Let the Good Times Roll" (not the <a href="Shirley%20and%20Lee">Shirley and Lee</a> song) and "Bumpin' and Stompin'." His recording for the label, "Just What The Doctor Ordered", remained unissued until 1990, when it was included on a <a href="compilation%20album">compilation album</a> of his Spring singles on the <a href="United%20Kingdom">UK</a> label, Ace/Kent. A move then to <a href="RCA%20Records">RCA Records</a> resulted in three singles and an album, produced by the <a href="Los%20Angeles%2C%20California">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="California">California</a> producer/singer <a href="Leon%20Haywood">Leon Haywood</a>.
In 1979, Green moved to California, and eventually signed with a small independent label, Ocean-Front Records for an album produced by <a href="Lamont%20Dozier">Lamont Dozier</a> and <a href="Arleen%20Schesel">Arleen Schesel</a>, the latter of whom Green later married. The album featured a re-worked version of a major hit for Dozier 10 years earlier, "<a href="Trying%20to%20Hold%20on%20to%20My%20Woman">Trying to Hold on to My Woman</a>". When the label closed, Green continued to record and self-release. In 2011, Green signed a deal for a brand new album with Special Soul Music, a new division of the label CDS Records. The album, entitled "I Should've Been The One", was released February 2012. It was his first album of new material in 29 years.
